name: Auto-GPT

score_rationale.persistence: Released March 2023, ~3 years. Continuous development but peak hype passed. Active GitHub repository.
score_rationale.autonomy: Chains together LLM thoughts to autonomously achieve goals. Breaks user-defined goals into sub-tasks. Self-plans, executes, refines based on feedback. High autonomy within task scope.
score_rationale.cultural_impact: Ignited Spring 2023 AI agent craze. Mainstream media coverage (Fortune, Fast Company). Defined public conception of 'autonomous AI agent.' BabyAGI, AgentGPT followed.
score_rationale.economic_reality: Open-source, no direct revenue model. High API costs for users. Spawned ecosystem of agent frameworks but limited commercial success for project itself.
score_rationale.governance: Open-source (Significant Gravitas). Community contributions. No formal governance structure.
score_rationale.tech_distinctiveness: First mainstream implementation of autonomous goal-pursuing agent. Task decomposition, real-time feedback refinement. Pioneered the 'agent loop' pattern.
score_rationale.narrative_coherence: 'AI that achieves goals for you.' Clear, compelling pitch. Associated with AGI aspirations (and risks). Strong narrative even if exaggerated.

curator_notes: Auto-GPT, released by Toran Bruce Richards in March 2023, ignited the autonomous AI agent craze. The project demonstrated that GPT-4 could chain together reasoning steps to autonomously pursue user-defined goals, breaking them into sub-tasks and refining approaches based on feedback. While technically limited (high API costs, tendency to loop), Auto-GPT's cultural impact was enormousâ€”it defined public understanding of AI agents and spawned imitators like BabyAGI and AgentGPT. Richards originally wanted an AI to email him daily AI news; he ended up creating the template for the 2023-2024 agent explosion.

evidence.claim: Ignited Spring 2023 AI agent craze, mainstream media coverage
Chains LLM thoughts to autonomously achieve goals via task decomposition
